resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript:
Welcome to the U C Path Salary Cap/MCOP worksheet training module.

This course will teach you how to use this page in UCPath

You can jump to a specific section of this module by clicking the menu link at the top left of the screen to open then menu, and then selecting the slide you would like to view.

If you wish to view the closed captions for this training module, click the speech bubble icon at the bottom of the player.

We have added files relevant to this training under the Resources link.

At times during this training, we may ask you to click an object on the screen to trigger an action, or click the next button to advance the course.


If you'd like to take notes, please download and print the Course Companion.

Click next when you are ready to get started

The Salary Cap / MCOP Worksheet is used to set up complex funding, such as funding subject to salary cap rates or positions with multiple components of pay such as Health Sciences Compensation Plan (HSCP) employees.

It is accessible from the Funding Entry page, as shown on the navigation path, and accessed via a link at the bottom right of the page.
From the Funding Entry page, select the Add new value tab.

Enter your search criteria, and click the add button.

This Salary Cap/ MCOP Worksheet training module will not cover the non-worksheet portions of the Funding Entry page. We cover the Funding Entry page in detail on the Funding Entry & Updates training module. The Link to that training is available on this page and under the Resources menu.

The Funding Entry page opens up.

It displays the Salary Cap / MCOP Worksheet link only for a filled position with a single incumbent and there is a Capped Fund or a Health Sciences Compensation Plan (HSCP) employee with multiple components of pay, or both.

Lets stop here for a moment.

If you attempt to enter funding on the Funding Entry page instead of the Salary Cap/M COP Worksheet and the employees salary is above the cap, the system displays an error and you cannot save the data. You Must use the Salary Cap / MCOP Funding Worksheet.


If the employees salary is below the cap, the system displays a warning message. You can decide whether to use the Salary Cap / MCOP Funding Worksheet or the Funding page.


When entering funding for a Health sciences compensation plan (HSCP) employee with multiple components of pay, you must use the salary cap/M cop funding worksheet.
Click the Salary MCOP worksheet link to open it.

The salary cap/mcop funding worksheet opens up.

Lets take a look at the different areas of this worksheet.

In this example we can see how a regular the Salary Cap/MCOP Funding worksheet for a regular faculty with capped funding looks link.

Similarly, the Compensation Data Snapshot section displays the incumbent employee's compensation data from Job Data, including Salary Plan, Salary Grade, Step, Comp Frequency and FTE.

This is view-only data to help you complete the MCOP worksheet.

Click to continue.

-----

In this example we can see how a regular the Salary Cap/MCOP Funding worksheet for a regular faculty with capped funding looks like.

Similarly, the Compensation Data Snapshot section displays the incumbent employee's compensation data from Job Data, including Salary Plan, Salary Grade, Step, Comp Frequency and FTE.

This is view-only data to help you complete the MCOP worksheet.

Click to continue.

Lets stop here for a moment, and understand how the worksheet areas relate to each other.

For HSCP employees with multiple components of pay, the percentage per Ern Code must equal the total percentage in the Compensation Data Snapshot. In this example, the sum of the Percent of Effort for all of the HSR rows should equal 42.285714 as displayed in the Compensation Data Snapshot.

In the Default Funding Profile section, the Earn Code should be blank, the OTC Indicator is No for the default funding FAU and Yes if there is above-the-cap funding. The Distribution % should equal 100% per Ern Code and OTC Indicator combination.

The Pay Component details from the employee's job earnings distribution (JED) from Job Data are displayed, including the earnings codes, and the monthly and annual dollar amount breakdowns, and the breakdown percentage per Earnings Code (HSR, HSP, HSN, and HOS if applicable for HSCP employees and REG for non HSCP employees.
In the next section of this training, we are going to look at different scenarios in which the M COP worksheet is used.

Lets start with an employee whose position requires the use of the Salary Cap/M Cop worksheet.

All Health Sciences Compensation Plan (HSCP) faculty with multiple components of pay - x, x prime, and y - must use the worksheet regardless of salary capped funding.
When opening the Funding Entry page, we need to click the plus button to add a row in order to edit the funding entry page.
Notice that the fields open up for data entry. However, as we mentioned before, all the changes must be made on the M COP worksheet.
Before we move to the M COP worksheet, we must enter the Funding effective date here.
Now click the link to open the M COP worksheet.

The worksheet opens up.

Lets take a look at the different areas of the worksheet for this HSCP employee.

The compensation Data snapshot area lists information from Job.

Notice that theres a percentage associated to each of the earning codes.

This is the Default Funding profile section where the default FAU and the Above-the-Cap funding are entered.

Scroll to the right to find the plus button to add a row.
Click the view all button to display all rows and to bring the row that you just added to the top of the section.

Keep in mind that you will add a row only if this section needs to be edited.
Enter the Funding Effective Date, it should be the same date that you entered in the main Funding Entry page.

Observe the Funding Distribution worksheet. Well have to add a row by scrolling to the right and clicking the plus button, and then, since this example has multiple rows, we select 1 to go to the editable area.

Alternatively, you can click the view all button to display all effective dated records.

Observe that this employee does have a salary cap, and we can tell it because there is a value in the Cap Type field, as you can see on the screen.

We need to identify the non-sponsored funding source that will pay the above the cap amount.

In this case the cap rate is $192,300.00. However, the employee compensations is $192,500; therefore,, the amount above the cap for that distribution must be charged to the above the cap account.

The over the cap amount will be charged to this row.

Observe that the OTC, or over the cap indicator must be set to Yes.
The chart-account that will be charged for the above the cap amount is entered here.

At times, you may need to split the over the cap amount into 2 different accounts.

So a row must be added to enter the full accounting unit, such as chart-account, project number, etc.

Then the percentage of the fund can be split between the accounts.

Now observe the first row with the Default Funding Profile. It has the OTC, or over the cap indicator set as NO.

This row is used as a backup account in case the total compensation is not fully distributed in the Funding Distribution Worksheet. This will be visible when you click on the Funding Distribution Preview.

Now lets talk about how to enter funding to the Funding Distributions Worksheet.

Here we have to enter the funding begin and end date by row, as well as the FAU.

Please note that you must enter an earn code to each row of the funding distribution worksheet. It cannot be left blank.

Now lets examine the columns identifying the distribution.

Notice that data has been entered to the Total allocated amount column,

however, there are 2 more areas where pay can be entered as you can see highlighted on the screen.

Deleting the data in the total allocated amount cell, and tabbing out of it, enables these two other cells.

When you enter a value in one of these three fields and tab out, the system will derive the other 2 fields.. If you are distributing by percentage, we recommend using the Percent of Effort field.
One more important thing to note: for the HSCP population, each earn code has a percentage associated with it.

Observe that in this example the Earn codes HSR,
HSP, HSN and HOS have different percentage associated with them.
The sum of the percentage of all the codes equals 100%.
In addition, the sum of the percentage of each code, for instance the HSR code highlighted here,
must equal the amount on the Compensation Data snapshot area.

We want to bring to your attention that in the main Funding Entry page, the total percentage per Ern code must equal 100%, however this rule is not applied to the worksheet.

On the Salary Cap/M COP worksheet, the Percent of Effort percentage must equal the total percentage of the specific Earn code.

Its worth noticing that cap rates are changed by the sponsors every so often.

UCPath will default to apply the current cap rate. If the incumbent is subject to a previous cap rate, click the magnifying glass and select the correct rate.

Once youve completed all of the changes, click the Funding Distribution Preview button at the bottom left of the page.

The system will display a preview of how the changes will load funding distributions to the main Funding Entry page.

In other words, the system will translate the changes back to the specifications of the Funding Entry page, which is 100% per earn code.

Note that clicking on the Return to Funding Entry link will delete all of your changes and return to the main Funding Entry page.

If you need to make changes, click the Return to Salary Cap/M cop funding worksheet.

Or, if you are ready to commit to your changes, click the Submit to Funding Entry button.

The changes are now reflected in the main Funding Entry page.
Observe the OTC indicator displaying a value in the OTC Indicator column. For each funding row that is subject to salary cap, the up-to-the-cap row is indicated by the N value and the over-the-cap row is indicated by the Y value.

If we look back at the worksheet, we can observe that there are 4 funding sources have capped funding, meaning that on these four instances where the indicator displays Y, , the funding is charged the over-the-cap account.

Observe how this data is translated into the Funding Entry page.

There is one more thing we want to point out.

Observe that the last row contains the default funding FAU from the Default Funding Worksheet section of the Worksheet and has a blank Earn Code at the percentage from the Worksheet (usually 100%). As mentioned before, any distribution shortages above will be charged to this funding row.

Before you submit the funding Entry page, there is one more thing that we suggest: type in the initiator name, in the initiator comment box to help your Approver see who initiated the transaction in case they have questions.

Now we click the Save button.

After saving the page, the submit button will appear at the bottom of the screen.
Click the button to submit the page.

In this scenario, well look at a non HSCP employee.

Start by defining your search criteria, and clicking the add button.

The Funding Entry page opens up.

Click the plus button to add a new funding Effective Dated row.

Enter the funding effective date here.

Since there is some over the cap funding in this entry, we need to edit it using the Salary Cap/ M cop funding worksheet.

So, we click the link to get to the worksheet.

Note that the Salary Cap/MCOP Funding Worksheet is only available when there is an incumbent in the position. It will not be used when the Position is unfilled.

We land on the Salary Cap/ M Cop Funding Worksheet .
Lets stop here and understand each of the section of the worksheet.
The Compensation Data Snapshot provides information about the Job, such as the compensation frequency and FTE. Observe that this is a .21 FTE position. The Monthly and Annual amounts displayed are the pro-rated amounts.
This is the Default Funding profile section where the default FAU and the Above-the-Cap funding are entered.

Scroll to the right to find the plus button to add a row.
Click the view all button to display all rows and to bring the row that you just added to the top of the section.

Keep in mind that you will add a row only if this section needs to be edited.

Enter the Funding Effective Date, it should be the same date that you entered in the main Funding Entry page.

In the Default Funding Profile section, the Earn Code should be blank. In this example there are two rows with two unique Accounts and OTC Indicators.

The OTC Indicator is No for the default funding FAU and Yes for above-the-cap funding.

The Distribution % should equal 100% per Ern Code and OTC Indicator combination.

If you need to add or remove an account, use the plus or minus buttons.
Now lets talk about how to enter funding to the Funding Distributions Worksheet.

Scroll to the right to find the plus button.

Click it to add a row.

Click the view all to bring the editable row to the top.
Lets take a close look at the funding distribution, and the data available in this area.

Notice that the monthly compensation of this employee is $2,876.91, however the cap rate is $2,593.

So, the difference of $282.94 will be charged to the Over the cap account indicated in the Default Funding Profile section with the OTC Indicator of Yes.

In the Funding distribution worksheet, you must enter the begin and end dates.


In addition, the earn code may not be left blank. For non-HSCP employees, the Earn Code should be REG.


If there are multiple funding distributions, click the + button to add an additional row or rows. Make sure the sum of the Percent of Effort column equals 100%.

There is one more thing we want to point out on the columns identifying the distribution.

Notice that data has been entered to the Total allocated amount column,

however, there are 2 more areas where pay can be entered as you can see highlighted on the screen.

Deleting the data in the total allocated amount cell, and tabbing out of it, enables these two other cells.

When you enter the percent of pay, the system will derive the other 2 fields.

When you enter a value in one of these three fields and tab out, the system will derive the other 2 fields.. If you are distributing by percentage, we recommend using the Percent of Effort field.

When you are finished with your worksheet edits, click the Funding distribution preview button.

Note that clicking on the Return to Funding Entry link will delete all of your changes.

This preview will combine the up to the cap and over the cap funding distribution rows in the same section. It is a preview of how your entries will be committed to the Funding Entry Page.

You can return to the worksheet page if you need to make any changes,

or click the submit to funding entry page to finalize it.

Before clicking the Save button, enter the name of the initiator and any other helpful information in the Initiator Comment box.

Then click save.

After saving the page, the submit button becomes available.

If you need to notify another user that this transaction has been submitted, you can use the notify button.

When you are ready, click the button to submit the page.

This concludes this course.

Please click next to continue.

Thank you for watching!

Visit the UC Davis UC Path website for more training resources and job aids.

If you have questions or suggestions, please drop us an email.

Click next to close the course.
